misconceptions.name: Reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for two coordinate points and reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from the user as input for this program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should prompt for and read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, typically as an int or double.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions coordinates instead of a grade
Four separate numeric inputs are read instead of one
No variable representing a single grade value is read from input
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements, likely reusing code for a distance-between-points problem instead of the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and four nextDouble() calls with a single prompt like "Enter grade: " and a single nextInt() or nextDouble() call storing the grade.
related_concepts: Mapping problem description to input variables
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads four doubles labeled as coordinates and never reads a single grade value, which directly contradicts the specification.

evidence.note: Prompts and reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic to classify grade into letter ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any conditional (if/else) logic to map a numeric grade into letter categories A, B, C, D, or F; instead it computes a distance using the input values.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute and print the distance between two points; no grade classification logic is necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to check the numeric grade against the specified ranges and assign the correct letter grade.
symptoms: No if, else if, or else statements appear in the program
No comparison of the input value to grade ranges like 90–100 or 80–89
Computation performed is unrelated to grade classification (distance formula instead)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a solution for a different problem (distance formula) and never implemented any grade range logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a single grade value, add an if/else if/else chain that checks whether the grade is in 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, or below 60, and assign the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional statements in the file at all, and all arithmetic relates to a distance formula, not grade ranges.

evidence.note: Computes a distance instead of using conditionals to classify a grade; no if/else logic appears anywhere in the program.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance statement instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a message about the distance between two points rather than printing a letter grade such as 'Letter grade: B' based on the input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The desired output is a sentence reporting the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The desired output should be a letter grade corresponding to the numeric grade, e.g., 'Letter grade: B'.
symptoms: Output label mentions 'distance of the two points' instead of 'Letter grade'
No character variable or string representing a letter grade is produced
Output value is a double distance, not a letter
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the task or reuse of code from a distance-calculation assignment instead of implementing the grade calculator output format.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After determining the letter grade, print it in the format 'Letter grade: X', where X is the computed letter.
related_concepts: Mapping computed results to user-friendly messages
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only printed message refers to distance, which directly contradicts the required 'Letter grade: ...' output.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Prints a distance message instead of a letter grade like 'Letter grade: B'.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Task Misalignment
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points, completely failing to address the required Grade Calculator problem. This shows a complete failure to understand or execute the core requirements of the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may have confused this assignment with a previous one or fundamentally misunderstood the prompt, believing the distance calculation was the correct task, or copied code without checking the requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required task was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Reads four inputs instead of one
Performs mathematical calculation inappropriate for grade assignment
Output text references distance, not grades
Absence of conditional logic (if/else)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the required program objective or reusing code from an incorrect context.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Identify the required inputs, processing logic (using if/else for ranges), and required output format.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates distance between two points and contains none of the elements required for a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) suitable for a distance problem, instead of the single grade input required.
Calculation uses the geometric distance formula instead of grade comparison logic.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Output describes the distance, confirming the program addresses the wrong problem entirely.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing Conditional Logic Structure
misconceptions.description: The student code contains no conditional statements (if, else if, else) necessary for mapping numeric ranges (grades) to categorical outputs (letter grades). The assignment relies entirely on control flow structures.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either misunderstood that grade assignment requires branching logic or simply solved the wrong problem (distance formula) which did not require conditional logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade calculation requires partitioning the input space (0-100) using `if/else if/else` statements to check if the grade falls into the range for A, B, C, D, or F.
symptoms: No `if` or `else` keywords found in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: The core logic required for the assignment was omitted due to solving an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the lecture material on control flow statements. Remember that complex decision-making based on input ranges requires if/else if/else chains.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code block is strictly sequential and lacks any form of conditional branching required for grading.

evidence.note: The entire program logic processes data sequentially without any necessary conditional checks (if/else), making grade calculation impossible.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or a copy-paste error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the correct problem, or has submitted code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student should have written a program that: (1) reads a single numeric grade (0-100), (2) uses conditional statements to evaluate which range it falls into, and (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
Output shows distance calculation, not letter grade
Prompt says 'Enter x1 and y1' instead of 'Enter grade'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted the wrong file, did not read the problem statement carefully, or copied code from a different assignment without modification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem specification carefully. The assignment requires reading ONE numeric grade and outputting a letter grade. Start fresh with: (1) Scanner to read the grade, (2) if-else statements to check ranges 90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, and below 60, (3) System.out.println() to display the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Near certain - the submitted code is objectively solving a different problem (distance calculation) than what was assigned (grade calculator). The inputs, logic, and outputs are completely incompatible with the requirements.

evidence.note: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single numeric grade as specified in the problem

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Code calculates and outputs Euclidean distance, not a letter grade for 0-100 numeric input

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to read two points and compute the distance between them instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads coordinates for two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read one numeric grade (0–100) and, using conditional checks on numeric ranges, print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompt asks for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program reads four double values rather than one numeric grade.
Program does not use any conditionals or range checks for grades.
Output describes distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of a solution for a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and start from scratch: prompt for a single integer/double grade (0–100), then use if/else-if conditions to check which range it falls in and print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Conditionals and if/else chains in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing a geometric distance and does not attempt any grade-related logic, which clearly does not match the assignment specification.

evidence.note: All input and output relate to coordinates and distance; there is no reading of a grade or mapping to a letter grade as specified in the problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator' problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or used code from a previous assignment (distance calculation) without adapting it or starting the required assignment (grade calculation).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and apply conditional logic to determine the letter grade, which requires reading one input and using if/else statements based on grade ranges.
symptoms: The code asks for four input values ('x1 and y1', 'x2 and y2') instead of one grade.
The core logic calculates distance using the distance formula instead of performing grade classification.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion regarding the assignment requirements, likely due to submitting irrelevant code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the grade calculator problem description carefully and remove all code related to distance calculation. The program must only read one numerical input (the grade) and use if/else structures to determine the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student's code is functionally correct for a different task (distance formula) but bears absolutely no resemblance to the required grade calculator program, failing every single rubric point.

evidence.note: The code reads four inputs for coordinates instead of a single grade.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The core logic calculates and prints the distance, confirming the code addresses the wrong problem.
